Learning_Objectives.objective_text: Define inertia and its relationship to mass
Understand the concept of net force
Distinguish between kinetic and potential energy
Expand algebraic expressions using distributive property
Classify triangles by sides and angles
Describe the structure of an atom
Determine atomic mass and atomic number
Identify function of nucleus, mitochondria, cell membrane
Trace energy flow in food webs

Key_Terms.definition: Resistance of any physical object to any change in its velocity
A push or pull upon an object resulting from interaction with another object
A measure of the amount of matter in an object
The vector sum of all forces acting on an object
The rate of change of velocity per unit of time
Stored energy due to position or state
The rate at which work is done (Watts)
Sum of potential and kinetic energy
A circuit with only one path for current
A circuit with multiple paths for current
A letter representing an unknown number
A fixed value that does not change
Terms that have identical variable parts
Longest side of a right triangle
An outcome or set of outcomes
Events where one outcome does not affect the other
Central part of atom containing protons/neutrons
Same element with different number of neutrons
Atom with a charge (lost or gained electrons)
Rigid outer layer of plant cells
Variant form of a gene (e.g., Blue vs Brown eyes)
Trait that shows up if present (Capital letter)
Trait that is hidden by dominant (Lowercase)
Organism that makes its own food (plants)

Study_Content.content_text: Isaac Newton's three laws of motion describe the relationship between the motion of an object and the forces acting on it.
An object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
When a car stops suddenly, your body keeps moving forward due to inertia. Seatbelts provide the unbalanced force to stop you.
Inertia is a property of matter, not a force that pushes you.
F = ma
Force equals mass times acceleration. The more mass an object has, the more force is needed to accelerate it.
Acceleration is directly proportional to Force and inversely proportional to Mass.
For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Forces always come in pairs.
Action and reaction forces act on DIFFERENT objects, so they do not cancel each other out!
A rocket pushes gas down (action), and the gas pushes the rocket up (reaction).
In physics, work is done only when a force moves an object. Pushing a wall and not moving it means zero work is done!
W = F \cdot d
The force must be in the same direction as the movement for maximum work.
A roller coaster at the top has high Potential Energy. As it falls, it converts to Kinetic Energy.
Watch how energy transforms.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Visualizing how Potential Energy converts to Kinetic Energy.
A swinging pendulum constantly swaps PE and KE. It stops eventually only because of air resistance (friction).
A closed loop that allows current to flow. Requires a source (battery), load (bulb), and wires.
In Series, if one bulb goes out, they all go out. In Parallel, others stay on.
V = I \cdot R
Electronics use resistors to control current so delicate components don't burn out.
Voltage is like water pressure, Current is like water flow, Resistance is like a narrow pipe.
P = I \cdot V
Never connect positive directly to negative without a load! It creates dangerous heat.
Algebra is generalized arithmetic. We use letters to represent numbers we don't know yet.
Visual breakdown of 3x + 5
You can only add terms if they have the same variable part. 2x + 3x = 5x, but 2x + 3y cannot be combined.
x and x² are NOT like terms!
a(b + c) = ab + ac
If you buy 3 shirts for $x each and 2 pants for $y each, total cost is 3x + 2y.
Factoring is the reverse of expanding. 2x + 4 = 2(x + 2).
Triangles can be classified by sides (equilateral, isosceles, scalene) or angles (acute, obtuse, right).
The sum of angles in ANY triangle is always 180°.
Used to find a missing side in a right-angled triangle. c is always the hypotenuse.
A = \frac{1}{2}bh
Builders use the 3-4-5 rule (Pythagoras) to check if corners are perfectly square.
When calculating area, the height must be at a 90° angle to the base.
Probability ranges from 0 (Impossible) to 1 (Certain). Fractions, decimals, or percentages can be used.
P(A) = \frac{\text{favorable outcomes}}{\text{total outcomes}}
Rolling a 6 on a standard die has a 1/6 chance.
P(Not A) = 1 - P(A). Chance of rain is 20%, chance of NO rain is 80%.
For independent events (like flipping two coins), multiply the probabilities.
Past results do not affect independent future results. The coin doesn't "remember" it was heads.
All matter is made of atoms. They are the smallest unit of an element.
Protons (+ charge) and Neutrons (no charge) are in the center. Electrons (- charge) zoom around the outside.
Visualizing the atom.
Atoms are mostly empty space. If the nucleus was a marble, the atom would be a stadium!
We use Carbon-14 (an isotope) to figure out how old ancient fossils are.
Simplified view of electron shells
The periodic table organizes all known elements by atomic number and chemical properties.
Columns are called Groups (elements behave similarly). Rows are called Periods.
Group 18 elements are "Noble Gases" - they are very stable and don't like to react (like Neon signs).
Metals are on the left (shiny, conduct), Non-metals on the right (dull, insulate). Staircase line separates them.
Hydrogen is in Group 1 but it is a NON-METAL gas, not a metal.
Color coded regions
Atoms bond to become stable, usually by getting a full outer shell of electrons (Octet Rule).
One atom STEALS electrons from another. Creates + and - ions that attract.
Ionic bonds usually happen between a metal and a non-metal (e.g., NaCl).
Atoms SHARE electrons. Like two people holding hands.
H2O is a covalent bond
Salt is Ionic (high melting point), Sugar is Covalent (low melting point).
Cells are the basic structural and functional units of life.
The POWERHOUSE of the cell. Generates energy (ATP).
The BRAIN. Contains DNA and controls cell activity.
Plant cells have Cell Walls and Chloroplasts. Animal cells do not.
Comparison diagram
Red blood cells have no nucleus to carry more oxygen. Nerve cells are long to send signals.
DNA holds the instructions for building and operating an organism.
DNA looks like a twisted ladder. The rungs are base pairs (A-T, C-G).
Dominant traits (like brown eyes) often hide recessive traits (like blue eyes).
A tool to predict the probability of offspring traits.
Crossing Bb x Bb
You get half your DNA from mom and half from dad.
An ecosystem includes all living things in an area interacting with each other and their environment.
Biotic = Living (Wolf). Abiotic = Non-living (Water).
Energy starts from the Sun -> Producers -> Consumers.
90% of energy is lost at each level (heat, movement). Only 10% is passed on.
Sun -> Grass -> Rabbit -> Fox
Fungi and bacteria recycle nutrients back into the soil. Without them, we would be buried in waste!

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Which property of an object determines its inertia?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Mass is a direct measure of inertia.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: If you double the force on an object, what happens to its acceleration?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Acceleration is directly proportional to force (F=ma).

Quiz_Questions.question_text: A 10kg object accelerates at 2 m/s². What is the force?
Which law explains why a book sits still on a table?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: 1st Law: Objects at rest stay at rest unless acted on by unbalanced force.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Action and reaction forces are always...
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Newton's 3rd Law states they are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: What is the unit for Work?
A ball held 2m high has what type of energy?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: It has potential due to gravity.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: If you lift a 5kg box 2 meters, how much work did you do? (g=10)
Energy of motion is called...
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Kinetic comes from the Greek word "kinesis" (motion).

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Can energy be destroyed?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Law of Conservation of Energy states it cannot be created or destroyed.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: What flows in a circuit?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Current is the flow of electrons.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: In which circuit type do all lights go out if one breaks?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Series circuits have only one path.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: If V=12V and R=4Ω, what is the Current?
What unit measures Resistance?
What happens to current if resistance increases (Voltage constant)?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Current and Resistance are inversely proportional.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Simplify: 3x + 4y - x
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Combine 3x and -x to get 2x. 4y stays separate.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Expand: 2(x + 3)
What is the coefficient in 5y?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: The number multiplying the variable is the coefficient.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Are 3x and 3x² like terms?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: No, because the exponents are different.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Evaluate 2x + 1 when x = 4
Which triangle has all equal sides?
Calculate the hypotenuse if sides are 3 and 4.
Sum of angles in a triangle?
Area of a triangle with base 10 and height 5?
A triangle with angles 90, 45, 45 is...
Probability of flipping heads?
Probability of rolling a 7 on a standard die?
If P(Win) = 0.4, what is P(Lose)?
Probability of flipping heads TWICE in a row?
The set of all possible outcomes is called...
Which particle has a positive charge?
Where are electrons found?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Electrons orbit in shells/clouds around the nucleus.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Atomic number tells you the number of...
Isotopes have different numbers of...
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Isotopes are same element (same protons) but different mass (neutrons).

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Most of an atom is...
Quiz_Questions.explanation: The nucleus is tiny compared to the electron cloud volume.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Elements in the same column usually have...
Which group contains the Noble Gases?
Where are metals found on the table?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Metals make up the majority of the left side.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Horizontal rows are called...
Which element is a non-metal in Group 1?
In a covalent bond, electrons are...
Ionic bonds occur between...
What charge does an atom get if it loses an electron?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Losing a negative electron leaves a net positive charge.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: NaCl (Table Salt) is...
Why do atoms bond?
Which organelle produces energy?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Mitochondria perform cellular respiration to make ATP.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: What is found in plant cells but NOT animal cells?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: Cell Wall provides rigid structure for plants.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Control center of the cell?
Simple cells like bacteria are...
Photosynthesis happens in...
What molecule carries genetic info?
Shape of DNA?
If B is Brown (dominant) and b is blue (recessive), what is Bb?
Physical appearance is called...
Probability of bb from Bb x Bb?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: 1 out of 4 squares will be bb.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: Which is an abiotic factor?
Organisms that make their own food are...
How much energy is passed to the next level?
Quiz_Questions.explanation: 10% rule. Rest is lost as heat.

Quiz_Questions.question_text: A network of interconnected food chains is a...
What is the primary source of energy for Earth?
